meanings.definition: To drag or pull something with force
meanings.sent1: She had to harl the heavy box across the room.
meanings.sent2: The workers had to harl the net out of the water.
meanings.sent3: The kids decided to harl the rope to see who was stronger.
meanings.sent4: He had to harl himself up the steep hill.
meanings.sent5: The horse had to harl the carriage up the muddy slope.

meanings.definition: A tangled mass of fibers or threads
meanings.sent1: The old rug had a harl of threads at the corner.
meanings.sent2: She brushed out the harl of yarn to untangle it.
meanings.sent3: The cat played with the harl of wool, making a mess.
meanings.sent4: The harl of hair in the drain needed to be cleaned out.
meanings.sent5: The harl of wires behind the TV looked messy.

meanings.definition: To throw or cast something forcefully
meanings.sent1: He would harl the ball as far as he could in the game.
meanings.sent2: She harled the stone into the pond, causing ripples.
meanings.sent3: The angry player decided to harl his racket in frustration.
meanings.sent4: The chef would harl the dough to flatten it for baking.
meanings.sent5: The child would harl his toys across the room in a tantrum.
